item.title: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: library(knitr) hook_output = knit_hooks$get('output') knit_hooks$set(output = function(x, options) { # this hook is used only when the linewidth option is not NULL if (!is.null(n <- options$linewidth)) { x = knitr:::split_lines(x) # any lines wider than n should be wrapped if (any(nchar(x) > n)) x = strwrap(x, width = n) x = paste(x, collapse = '\n') } hook_output(x, options)}) ```{R eval=F} data(package = .packages(all.available = TRUE)) #0. Introduce your dataset and each of your variables (or just your main variables if you have lots) in a paragraph.

item.title: Data Wrangling and Exploratory Analysis
item.description: knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE) library(knitr) opts_chunk$set(fig.align="center", fig.height=5, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=8, tidy=TRUE) ##0 Introduction getwd() performance<-read.csv("exam.csv",TRUE,",") medicalcost<-read.csv("insurance.csv",TRUE,",") The first dataset is about student performance in three different(subjects) exams along with parental education level and completion of test preparation. The second dataset is about individual's medical cost charged by healthcare insurance companies. As I'm interested in healthcare and medicine, I'd like to know if there is any interesting relationship between student's performance and the cost of insurance with consideration of factors like economic, personal, and social.
